content.webTitle: Art buying was supposed to be disrupted by the internet – what happened?

fields.headline: Art buying was supposed to be disrupted by the internet – what happened?
fields.bodyText: You’d expect the art trade to have changed radically since auction houses first came into existence around 300 years ago. But the market is still dominated by two of the world’s oldest sales houses: 253-year-old Christie’s, and Sotheby’s – which turned 275 this year. Despite a flurry of online art sales startups launching over the past decade, many with the aim of disrupting the art world in the style of Spotify or Amazon, it’s still business as usual where the real money is. Most of the work sold by online art companies last year was under $5,000 (£3,900), with less than 10% above $250,000, according this year’s UBS/Art Basel Art Market Report. “There was all this talk about disrupting the market, that this was the end of the market and that everything was going to move online,” says Clare McAndrew, author of the Art Market Report. “In terms of disrupting, [online startups] haven’t really made the impact or overthrown the incumbents.” There have of course been technological advances in the way art is bought and sold. Some art fairs, galleries and sites have started trading in bitcoin and using blockchain as a way of authenticating artworks. You can buy a share in a Warhol or a Monet for less than £20 through blockchain-based online platforms. The global online art market grew 9.8% in aggregate in 2018 to $4.64bn , according to the 2019 Hiscox Online Art Trade Report. But the four online art platforms most trusted by buyers are Christie’s, Sotheby’s, Phillips and Bonhams, the report says, while forecasting “consolidation and casualties” among the new online startups in an overcrowded market. When it comes to high-stakes investments, collectors prefer to stay within the art establishment. “Collectors feel safer with the traditional established brands which give you a great peace of mind with the whole process, due diligence, authenticity, payment terms etc,” says London-based art adviser and collector Daniel Turriani. Sebastian Cwilich, the co-founder of New York-based art platform Artsy, believes many startups failed because the business is so complex and rooted in tradition. “Around the time we started, a lot of business launched with us,” he says. “Some of those no longer exist or are much smaller.” Artsy partners with auction houses, galleries and art fairs to sell works on its site. “We always believed that the ‘we’re going to replace everything and do it better ourselves’ approach wouldn’t work.” Marion Maneker, industry expert and publisher of Art Market Monitor, notes that there was a misguided assumption that people would buy art online sight unseen, like clothes or grocery shopping. “Art’s never been a retail business for the simple fact that art is not a necessary item. Art’s a wonderful thing but not a real requirement,” he says. In his view, the market’s biggest disruption happened a long time ago with the advent of email. “As soon as BlackBerries could handle a jpeg, people were buying and selling off of that.” Tawn Albright, a US-based tech executive who led the expansion of online gallery Saatchi Art into art fairs, says new platforms have helped open up the art world. “I spend hours on Invaluable [an art sales site] looking at things that would normally go out to auction. I don’t have to wait for the special invite,” he says. But, according to Michal Szczesny, chief executive of UK-based Artfinder, the high end is still a relatively closed shop. “The transparency of pricing and democracy of online selling is not something that suits the high end of the market or its collectors, who very much enjoy the physical VIP experience they receive through traditional auction houses,” he says. The art trade revolves around a network of relationships between auction houses, dealers, gallerists, collectors and advisers, presenting another barrier to entry. “Although information flow has been accelerated by the internet, email and Instagram, in many ways the art world remains quite old-fashioned and undemocratic,” says Teresa Krasny, a London-based art adviser. “Personal relationships between the collector and the major players are established over time.” But there’s a new generation of art buyers who are more comfortable purchasing art online. The Hiscox report found that 29% of millennial buyers surveyed said they preferred to buy art online, compared with 14% a year ago. Big auction houses use their online platforms to attract new buyers. “In future, the number one auction house will be the one that’s right now bringing in the next generation of collectors. Digital is where they are coming in,” says Matt Rubringer, Christies’ deputy chief marketing officer. AI continues to infiltrate the art world and, as well as creating artworks, is being used to predict what art buyers want. This year Sotheby’s acquired Thread Genius, a startup that personalises recommendations to clients using image recognition. But the tech is a long way from replacing human specialists. “Serious collectors generally have a clear sense of their acquisition goals. Their approach, which can be both intellectual and emotional, doesn’t lend itself easily to the product of an algorithm,” says Krasny. Machine learning is also being used in the push for greater transparency around pricing, with an image-recognition app called Magnus allowing users to see the cost of certain artworks by pointing a phone at them. The industry is notoriously opaque when it comes to revealing prices, which is a concern for online buyers and hinders the growth of the digital art trade. “Until prices are transparent, I think the upper echelon of the art market will continue to hold its own,” says Albright. In a sector where secrecy and exclusivity are considered vital components to doing deals, would-be disruptors have a battle on their hands.
